First, we'll speak with Ana Avendano, who handles immigration policy for the AFL-CIO.
Ms. Avendano, welcome to the program.
Happy to be here.
So clarify for us the AFL-CIO's position on a guest worker program.
The guest worker program is one part of our comprehensive approach to immigration reform.
We are opposed to guest worker programs because they are a blueprint for exploitation of workers, but that's not the entire policy.

Our executive council adopted a historic resolution in the year 2000, embracing immigrant workers as part of our movement and right now we're advocating there strongly for full legalization for all twelve million undocumented workers.
You say that a guest worker program is licensed for exploiting workers?
Right.
There's never been a single guest worker program that worked to the benefit the workers.
Under guest worker programs, by definition, workers come to this country tied to an employer.
An employer not only controls the working conditions for that worker, but also controls the immigration status for that worker.

It is our position that is not good public policy to simply expand that program to include hundreds of thousands of workers who are going to be tied to their employer and, you know, ripe for exploitation.

Professor Ruth Milkman has written about the relationship between labor and immigrants.
She says there has traditionally been tension over this issue within the labor movement.
There was always a strain in the labor movement of hostility to immigrants, the view being that immigrant workers undercut the hard-won labor standards of native born American workers.

And then there's always been a second view, this is true for the whole time there's been a labor movement, nearly a century now in this country, that the right approach to this problem was to organize the immigrants and raise their labor standards to the level of others.
And these same kind of debates have actually taken place about other groups of workers.
Women, historically, were treated in just that same ambivalent way.
Black workers, to some extent.
You know, the original view of many people in the labor movement and elsewhere was that you could never organize undocumented immigrants, especially, or poor immigrants, more generally.
They were terrified of apprehension by the immigration authorities and deportation and so on.
Being caught, say, if their name was on a union roll.

pointed out that, she said, In my country if you organize a union, they kill you.

It began to occur to people that maybe the historical approach of the AFL-CIO needed to be re-thought.

So in a way that impulse is now concentrated and Change to Win and the AFL-CIO is left with the industrial unions on the one side, which have relatively few immigrant members, though they have some, and the public sector unions, which have hardly any immigrant members.

Lynn Toler wields the gavel on TV's ""Divorce Court."" She says there are ways to think our way out of the most challenging emotional situations.
It's a concept she calls emotional acuity, and she says it can keep you centered under the most trying of circumstances.
Now, Judge Toler's going to join us every other week as a regular contributor.
We're going to pick her brain on topics that she knows plenty about: family, family law, criminal justice, mental health.
Judge Toler's with us now to talk about ways to take control of our emotions and our lives.
Good to talk to you again.
Good to talk to you, too.
So explain: What exactly is mental acuity?
Emotional acuity is the ability to think your way through how you feel, and it is a response to the immediate response by a practiced process.

We spend a lot of time learning, these days, about math, and numbers, and figures, and English, and we don't take a lot of time to learn how to feel and to feel appropriately, to pick the emotions that we are going to have.
And it - our emotional preparation tends to be a very haphazard thing.

And what emotional acuity is, is the deliberate and purposeful development of emotional skills, which I think often has more to do with how well you do in a circumstance than the information that you have.
Well, why don't you give me an example?
I'll give you something in my own life, you know, that I struggle with.
Which is, sometimes I am, you know, I'm a bit on the weak side when it comes to controlling my eating habits, and I'm an emotional eater.
What would you say, you know, if someone is going - and that's not a criminal offense, but it's certainly not healthy.
If you're someone who keeps walking down the same emotional road over and over again, what do you do about that?
What's the emotional acuity that you have to apply there?
First you have to start way before you get upset.
You have to start at the door of the grocery store.

When you go in there, you have a list, and that list will be a list of all of the good things that you need to have in your house - none of the chips, none of the stuff that you love - because you on that day are going to decide you are going to control your emotions.
You're going to control how you eat, and you only bring that home.
Then you give it voice.
I gave mine voice.
I went through that myself, on the refrigerator.
And I put a picture of me when I was thin and me afterwards, what you really want to do, and actually put that on the refrigerator that I had to see.

The combination of those two things, having made a decision at the grocery store door only to bring those things in the house that I need to eat and will not eat outrageously and then having that reminder on the refrigerator door, that is preparing.
That's the process that you go through so the emotion of the moment doesn't get ahead of you because you're already prepared for it.
Let's talk about things that are much serious.
There are issues like, you know, assault and battery that happen between family members when emotions are out of control.
That's a whole magnitude of seriousness, and I'm sure you've seen a lot of it in your work over time.
How do you deal with people who really can be violent and criminal when they let their emotions get away from them?
Often I saw that in municipal court, and often I saw - I was seeing a lot more intergenerational domestic violence, sons and fathers, sons and mothers, a whole lot of abuse going on.
And what I found is I would find families that would repeat, come to my court over and over again.
And what I found is that they were in what I called high-volume households.
The emotional level is already at a keen pitch every morning.
And in order to get heard, in order for you to believe that you're going to be heard, you have to take it up a notch.
So it gets ratcheted up all day long.
There has to be someone in the house who decides we are going to deal with each other, one day when nobody's excited about anything, and talk about what's going on.
And when I had mothers in there that were like that and parents like that, I said don't address any issues of any significance while you are angry.
Walk out and leave.
